The emergence of the New Criticism school triggered considerable debate regarding the intentional fallacy. This idea revolves around the issue of whether the aesthetic intentions of an actor should influence the criticism and evaluation of their job. especially, it examines whether a piece of art should be assessed solely on its very merits, independent of the author 's intentions. 

 In 1946, William K. Wimsatt and Monroe Beardsley pu

The crux of the debate lies in whether or not an artist's intentions should play a role in the evaluation of their work. More specifically, it questions whether a work of art should be judged solely on its intrinsic qualities, regardless of the creator's motives. The emergence of New Criticism brought these issues to the forefront, challenging traditional notions of authorial intention and artistic interpretation.

The New Criticism school, which emerged in the mid-20th century, emphasized close reading of texts and focused on analyzing the literary work itself rather than considering external factors such as the author's biography or intentions. This approach aimed to remove subjective interpretations and biases, allowing for a more objective analysis of the text.

The debate surrounding the intentional fallacy continues to this day, with some critics arguing that understanding the author's intentions can provide valuable insights into the work, while others maintain that a work of art should be judged solely on its own merits.
